awd_titl_txt: US-Africa Workshop on Expanding the Africa Array Network to Support Multidisciplinary Science in Africa, Washington, DC
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Funding from this grant was used to support a workshop on June 2-4, 2010 at Howard University titled “US-Africa workshop on expanding the AfricaArray network to support multidisciplinary science in Africa”.   The objectives of the workshop were to 1) obtain community input on key science questions (multidisciplinary and discipline-specific) that cannot be addressed without new observations from Africa, 2) determine the observational infrastructure needed to provide cross-cutting and discipline-specific data sets for addressing the science questions, 3) explore the intersection and overlap between the observational infrastructure identified above and existing infrastructure within the AfricaArray network, and 4) investigate broader impacts, including best options for communicating and disseminating science information to government and non-government organization (NGOs) decision-makers and supporting educational activities in Africa and the U.S.

The proposed outcomes for the workshop were to 1) develop a science plan describing the rationale for developing a single instrumentation initiative the addresses the needs of several geoscience disciplines, 2) develop a logistics plan that outlines the observational needs for each science field and indicates how the existing AfricaArray network can be adapted to meet those needs, and 3) develop "broader impacts" plan discussing ways to support science education in Africa and the U.S. and how to effectively provide information to decision-makers in government agencies and NGOs.

The workshop was attended by over 80 participants from the U.S., Africa and Europe spanning a range of geoscience disciplines, including atmospheric science, climate science, geography, ecology, hydrology, geophysics, geodesy, and space weather. The workshop was organized in seven sessions. In the first session, overview talks on science projects and research questions were provided for each of the major disciplinary areas represented by the workshop participants. Sessions 2-5 consisted of working groups and reports back from the working groups to a plenary session. Session 6 consisted of a series of presentations that synthesized and reviewed the compelling multidisciplinary science that could be addressed with an expanded science network. In the final session, an outline for a new science plan for AfricaArray was discussed.

There was overwhelming interest from the workshop participants to move forward with expanding AfricaArray into an interdisciplinary network to support research and education across a range of geoscience fields.  Input was obtained from participants within each field on the compelling science questions that could be addressed with an expanded sensor network and the kinds of in-situ observations that are needed.  This information was condensed into a draft outline for a new science plan for AfricaArray, and writing assignments for the various parts of the plan were made at the end of the workshop.

Because of the broad interest in expanding AfricaArray, it was also decided that a follow-on workshop should be held in Africa to obtain additional and more far reaching input from scientists in Africa.  Following the workshop in June, plans were put together quickly to add to the annual AfricaArray workshop an additional two days of discussion about expanding AfricaArray.

The annual AfricaArray workshop held November 21-22 in Johannesburg, and was preceded on November 19-20 with discussions on vetting and revising the science and logistics plan for an expanded AfricaArray.  The four-day combined event was attended by about 80 participants from across Africa.
